greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest m > 1 such that m divides n^m-1.
comment: Each prime factor of n-1 is a solution of the equation Mod[n^x-1,x]=0, so a(n) is not greater than smallest prime factor of n-1. Conjecture 1: All terms of this sequence are primes. Conjecture 2: a(n) is the smallest prime factor of n-1 or For n>2 A092028(n)=A020639(n-1).
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 3..10000
example: a(8)=7 because 7 divides 8^7-1 and there doesn't exist an m such that 1<m<7 and m divides 8^m-1.
program: (PARI) a(n)=if(n%2, return(2)); my(m=3); while(Mod(n,m)^m!=1, m+=2); m \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 29 2014
results.author: _Farideh Firoozbakht_, Mar 26 2004
